name: Hillstead Outpost
description: A rugged village perched on wind-swept hills. Stone watchtowers overlook golden meadows. The people here are wary, their eyes fixed on the treeline — something is out there.

story_actions.story_text:
You arrive at Hillstead Outpost and are nearly knocked aside by a running child. A guard shouts, a wolf-horn sounds in the distance, and someone slams a door shut just ahead.

Whispers swirl around your presence. 'They came from the bridge?' — 'But the bridge was broken.' — 'Maybe the wolves followed them.'

No one has time to greet you properly. The village is in disarray.
A large hound lies wounded beneath a porch. A child pets its head while whispering, 'He tried to warn us.'
An elder woman grabs your arm. 'You crossed the bridge? Mirella sent you? Then maybe we’re not abandoned after all…'
You hear shouting. A courier mounts a horse and gallops toward the high road. 'Tell them Hillstead still stands!' someone calls after them.
You pass a home where someone bakes flatbread over a dying fire. The smell is nostalgic. The mood is anything but.
A trader curses over a soaked crate. 'The valley’s flooding again. Can’t send grain east. And there’s... shapes in the shallows now.'
Later that night, a traveling tinker tells you the waters have shifted again. A hidden stone path near the lake is visible now — but only barely.
A bloodied hunter paces near the outpost gates. 'Too many tracks. Too close. We’re being tested — and it’s not hunger.' He sees your hesitation and shakes his head. 'Go see for yourself.'
A lone priest rings the chapel bell. No one listens. No one comes. You catch him murmuring prayers for 'the pact' beneath his breath.

The priest lowers his voice. 'Before swords and stone towers, there was an agreement. Spirit for shelter. Blood for balance.'

He glances toward the forest. 'I fear we've forgotten our part.'
By the chapel altar, a faded banner hangs. You hadn’t noticed it before — twin wolves flanking a tree, their eyes stitched with golden thread.
The priest notices your curiosity. 'If you wish to understand the pact, you must read what came before. The chapel still holds fragments — prayers, warnings, agreements.'
Study weathered tomes and loose pages in the chapel archive. Much is missing — but pieces remain.
You close the last book. The message is clear now — the pact was not submission, but shared protection. You feel your understanding deepen.
Patrol the outer perimeter with hunter. The wind shifts. Somewhere beyond the treeline, something watches. A farmer says more livestock vanished last night, and no one saw what took them.
After a few patrols, the hunter stops you. 'They’re not testing our walls — they’re circling. If you follow the west ridge, you might catch a clearer sign.'

You venture further into the perimeter — but something calls you off the path. A low growl. A gust. Tracks.

You follow.

You find a tree marked with runes and dried fur. It hums faintly when you approach. You remember the banner from the chapel. From here, the forest thickens — but the watchtower might give you a clearer view of what lies ahead.
From the watchtower, you see movement between the trees. The air shifts. The gorge calls — not as danger, but as memory.
